body:
> However, I think the proper way of solving this might be evaluating the d:status tag and see if it is OK before parsing the properties.

I don't understand why the example you posted has two `d:status` fields, one OK and one not found?

The way the XML parsing works (it parses all the input at once), it might be best to do something very similar to what you suggested so just set the current time if the input time was empty.

Does that then work for you? Or does the status not found confuse it?

If so I suggest you send a pull request with that in.

Hello. Same error for me, with a context slightly different : I'm using Nextcloud (13) with an object store (Ceph / S3) as primary storage.

And I confirm that the hack of @buergi works. Thank you !
@buergi do you want to send a PR with your workaround in it?

I guess what is meant by the two propsets is that some properties are ok and others could not be retrieved. I don't know if this is in the standard or not.

We can use my suggestion as a hack, however, I'm not sure if this couldn't cause trouble when syncing. If the date is set to the current date when the actual date could not be retrieved this could maybe cause conflicts with real changes, or at least unnecessary syncing. 
What do you think?

I think your suggested fix is a good one. There is no time so rclone returning the current time is the correct thing to do.

I'm not sure what the 404 status is doing there, maybe it means that the date isn't available. Either way the object does exist doesn't it?

This could potentially cause excess syncing. This is easy to work around with the --size-only flag though.

However your workaround is a soft fail which means that things will carry on copying which is good user experience.

Perhaps we should warn the user once that the remote isn't returning modtimes. I probably wouldn't bother though as there are many other places in the rclone backends which do exactly the same thing. Maybe a debug would be a good idea.

The question is shall files with missing modtimes be skipped or forcefully copied (which is what setting modtime to now actually means, does it?). I would say skipping would be a better failsafe action than copying and maybe overwriting other changes is it?
I myself prefer not synced files over unintentionally overwritten files.

Maybe the best possible way to react is to ignore the modtime for items which don't have a valid one and rely on other attributes and if not sure not better not to sync than to overwrite something.

> The question is shall files with missing modtimes be skipped or forcefully copied (which is what setting modtime to now actually means, does it?). I would say skipping would be a better failsafe action than copying and maybe overwriting other changes is it?
I myself prefer not synced files over unintentionally overwritten files.

I see what you mean.

> Maybe the best possible way to react is to ignore the modtime for items which don't have a valid one and rely on other attributes and if not sure not better not to sync than to overwrite something

rclone doesn't have a concept of an individual modtime being invalid unfortunately.

The rclone way of doing this is to change the Precision of the backend from 1 second to `fs.ModTimeNotSupported`.  This tells the rest of rclone to ignore the mod times and use other things (like the size) to do the sync.

Resetting the Precision for the backend would be a good thing to do if **all** the files don't have a modtime.  Is that the case?

We didn't reach a resolution on this in time for 1.43.

I still think that @buergi 's original fix would be a step forward.  Maybe with an ERROR log?

Do you want to send a PR?

issue.title: webdav: add workaround for missing mtime - fixes #2420

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Workaround for #2420, maybe there is a better fix, but this will do for the moment.
I replaced the proposed Now() with unix time 0, as I think this is less arbitrary and prevents possible files without an mtime from constant overwriting during sync.

body: Ok, PR sent. To prevent files without mtime from constant overwriting I replaced the Now() with unix time 0. I think this is a better workaround that is less likely to cause troubles.
I've merged this now - I think I must have pushed it to the wrong place!  Thanks for the fix @buergi - ths will be in [the latest beta](https://beta.rclone.org) in 15 mins and in 1.44

@ncw I think I'm facing more general issue of incorrect time returned by server:

> rclone -V
> rclone v1.45
> - os/arch: linux/amd64
> - go version: go1.11.2

> rclone ls :webdav: --webdav-url https://webdav.mail.ru ...
> 2018/11/29 16:43:06 Failed to ls: couldn't list files: parsing time "Mon, 06 Jan 50470 09:13:20 GMT" as "2006-01-02T15:04:05Z07:00": cannot parse "Mon, 06 Jan 50470 09:13:20 GMT" as "2006"

I think it needs same sort of graceful treatment.
